description.narrative: Girls and boys participate in decisions that affect their lives to become agents of change in their schools and communities, including on environmental protection / climate change adaptations, which contributes to Adolescent Empowerment, Gender Discriminatory Roles And Practices, Skills Development. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: School-aged girls and boys, especially early adolescents (aged 10-14) [in targeted districts], acquire essential learning outcomes and practice skills for life, are safe from exploitation, harmful practices and violence, and benefit from integrated social services (including in emergencies).

participating-org.narrative: MINISTRY OF EDUCATION SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

sector.narrative: Adolescents participating in or leading civic engagement initiatives (including in humanitarian settings)
Development of multi-sectoral legislation/policies/strategies/action plans supporting development and participation of adolescents
Provision of skills development for multiple age groups (including in temporary learning spaces)
Social protection and welfare services policy, planning and administration

Malawi Programme Strategy Note Theory of Change (School-Age Children)
UNICEF Policy on Harmonized Approach to Cash Transfers to Implementing Partners
UNICEF Procedure on Harmonized Approach to Cash Transfers to Implementing Partners

UNICEF Tender Notices through the UN Global Marketplace

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Girls and boys participate in decisions that affect their lives to become agents of change in their schools and communities, including on environmental protection / climate change adaptations

description.narrative: Adolescents continue to be engaged in decision-making processes at the school-level via student clubs and councils, whilst the number of youth-led organisations registered with the National Youth Council continues to rise. One hundred and seventy-two children (106 girls and 66 boys) in Chikwawa, Machinga, Dedza and Mangochi are able to report on child rights issues in their communities and ignite dialogue with duty bearers on such issues through child led radio programs, blogs and newsletters as a result of UNICEF supported training in basic journalism skills. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:12/12/2019

title.narrative: Number of formal institutional structures (youth parliament, youth clubs and youth media) for children and youth to participate in decision making process
